metadata.synopsis: Volo is at players' camp. He shares some revelations when first time spoken to, but otherwise this is his default in-camp dialog.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Save Volo at the place of execution in the Docks, in front of the Steelwatch Foundry at approximately: -229; 4; -160

114.speaker: Volo
114.text: It is splendid to see you again, my friend.
114.context: NodeContext: grateful - he's seeing the player for the first time after they saved his life from an angry mob

155.speaker: Volo
155.text: If you hadn't saved me from that mob, I'd be penning a Guide to the Afterlife, based on first-hand experience.
155.context: NodeContext: grateful - he's seeing the player for the first time after they saved his life from an angry mob

0.speaker: Volo
0.text: Perhaps you would hazard a guess as to why the mob turned on me?
0.context: NodeContext: tentatively - he's not sure how much the player knows

34.speaker: Player
34.text: Orin the Red controls a syndicate of killers - perhaps you've pissed her off.

126.speaker: Volo
126.text: Quite right. But it's not Orin herself who has marked me for death. It is her dread master.
126.context: NodeContext: excited - building toward his big reveal on the next line

118.speaker: Volo
118.text: The Lord of Murder has returned.
118.context: NodeContext: with gravitas - a dramatic reveal

159.speaker: Volo
159.text: As he did a hundred years ago, Bhaal has set his accursed sights on Baldur's Gate, and his temple runs red with the blood of the innocent.
159.context: NodeContext: in full-on dramatic storyteller mode - he wants his audience (of one) hanging on every phrase

144.speaker: Volo
144.text: And just as then, he has more than one Chosen to manifest his gruesome plot. He has Orin.
144.context: NodeContext: Final sentence delivered to lead-in to the shock reveal coming in the next line, where he will directly accuse the player of being a child of Bhaal

21.speaker: Volo
21.context: NodeContext: an accusation, delivered with a little anxiety. He's accusing somebody of being a child of the god of murder so he's nervous

45.speaker: Player
45.text: I'm all he has - Orin is dead.

7.speaker: Volo
7.text: You triumphed over Bhaal's Chosen? Marvellous!

127.speaker: Player
127.text: A terrible fate awaits me, as I did not impress my Father. I don't like to think on it.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: No triumph, just a nightmare I can hardly recall.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: I am Bhaal's Chosen. This city is my abattoir.

102.speaker: Volo
102.text: I was hoping your better nature might come to the fore. Perhaps you never had one.
102.context: NodeContext: anxious but indignant as a child of Bhaal threatens him

26.speaker: Player
26.text: Yes - and claimed her power as my own.

14.speaker: Volo
14.text: And what will you do with that power? Slaughter the city? Brutalise the world?
14.context: NodeContext: anxious but indignant as a child of Bhaal threatens him

48.speaker: Volo
48.text: This is not the first time your kind have threatened Baldur's Gate, and the city still stands.

59.speaker: Volo
59.text: It will survive you. And so will I - from as great a distance as possible.
59.context: InternalNodeContext: Volo flees after this nodeNodeContext: preparing for a swift exit, but not actually fleeing until the dialogue ends

131.speaker: Player
131.text: Yes - and defied the Lord of Murder himself.

82.speaker: Volo
82.text: Such a historic deed must be documented in every gory detail.
82.context: NodeContext: excited - he loves a good story

115.speaker: Player
115.text: I did. Bhaal killed me for my troubles.

68.speaker: Volo
68.text: Slain by the Lord of Murder, and risen again to save Baldur's Gate. This is stupendous!
68.context: NodeContext: excited - he loves a good story

39.speaker: Volo
39.text: You and I shall pen the book of your experiences together!
39.context: NodeContext: excited - he loves a good story

43.speaker: Volo
43.text: My quill is trembling in anticipation! Tell me everything!
43.context: NodeContext: excited - he loves a good story

3.speaker: Player
3.text: I'll tell the tale better in my own words.

62.speaker: Volo
62.text: With the accompaniment of cacophonous tunes and gaudy dancing, no doubt? I shudder to think.
62.context: NodeContext: with a shudder in his voice - he'd rather tell the story HIS way. In a book.

145.speaker: Volo
145.text: But if you're content for your heroics to be reduced to theatrical fancies, I shan't stand in your way.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: I'll find a bard to write my tale - they'll do a better job.

122.speaker: Volo
122.text: A bard? The people want to hear the truth of the matter, not some trumped-up song and dance.
122.context: NodeContext: incredulous - he wants to tell the story in his own way

64.speaker: Volo
64.text: The battle in the Temple itself... it seems you followed in the bloody footsteps of the Gate's old Bhaalspawn hero.
64.context: NodeContext: fascinated, having just heard an account of a great victory won by the player

123.speaker: Volo
123.text: All the Coast shall read my writings of your triumph. Ha! Bhaal's seed has been wasted, spilled on the ground once again!

110.speaker: Player
110.text: It was traumatic. I really don't want to talk about it.

121.speaker: Volo
121.text: As you wish. Perhaps when the scars have healed we can reopen them. It will give the people of Baldur's Gate much hope to hear your tale.

101.speaker: Volo
101.text: And... thank you. For my life, for the stories, for all of it.
101.context: NodeContext: sincere - 'my life' because the player saved his life

136.speaker: Volo
136.text: Not an accusation - an observation, based on a thorough knowledge of your kind. And I note that your retort was not a denial.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: About one thing, yes. I'm the last - Orin is dead.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: No. It's true - but I reject Bhaal's influence.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: Not mistaken, but very foolish. Surely you know this means I can't let you live?

61.speaker: Player
61.text: Yes - you have this all wrong.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Bhaal does not have me - I reject his influence.

19.speaker: Volo
19.text: I see that. You have at least a measure of self-control, but Bhaal's inheritance is not shrugged off so easily.
19.context: NodeContext: encouraging, but with a note of caution (BAHL)

58.speaker: Player
58.text: So you know what I am. You should also know that means I can't let you live.

153.speaker: Volo
153.text: It means nothing of the sort.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: More lies, Volo. I'm no Bhaalspawn.

105.speaker: Volo
105.text: A pity. For Baldur's Gate may need Orin's counterpart if is to survive this crisis.

113.speaker: Volo
113.text: The heart of a Bhaalspawn is a flipped coin that lands on its edge.
113.context: NodeContext: dramatic - telling a legendary tale

158.speaker: Volo
158.text: Yours is a family set upon self-slaughter.
158.context: NodeContext: dramatic - telling a legendary tale

142.speaker: Volo
142.text: They are a family set upon self-slaughter.
142.context: NodeContext: dramatic - telling a legendary tale

130.speaker: Volo
130.text: When there are two or more, they will destroy one another until a single heir to the throne of blood remains.
130.context: NodeContext: dramatic - telling a legendary tale

88.speaker: Volo
88.text: In times gone by, there was an errant-hearted Bhaalspawn who stood against his foul father, and brother Sarevok.
88.context: NodeContext: dramatic - telling a legendary tale. Brother as in sibling rather than monk (SAH-reh-vok)

112.speaker: Volo
112.text: I had hoped my instincts regarding your heritage were correct, and that you were of similar heroic vintage.
112.context: NodeContext: slightly disappointed, but still holding onto hope

75.speaker: Volo
75.text: Optimist that I am, I hope you are of similar heroic vintage.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: I'm afraid you're mistaken. I'm nobody special.

124.speaker: Volo
124.text: That is not true, my friend. Whether you're descended from the gods or not, you have saved my hide more than once.

10.speaker: Volo
10.text: I believe you will save this city.

139.speaker: Volo
139.text: And I'd like to help, the only way I know how - with a Guidebook. This one did not flow from my quill, but from that of the wizard Irenicus.
139.context: NodeContext: sincere, despite the apparent humour of offering a Guidebook to fight a god. He takes it seriously. ((irɛnIkIs))

29.speaker: Volo
29.text: It is a study of the Slayer, and may give you a much-needed edge when you face Bhaal's Chosen.

66.speaker: Volo
66.text: The book seems to have escaped from me. I had it when I arrived at your camp, so I'm sure you'll find it somewhere hereabouts.
66.context: NodeContext: mildly surprised by his own absent-mindedness

41.context: CinematicNodeContext: Play generic give anim on Volo

15.speaker: Player
15.text: I already know plenty about the Slayer already - I can become it.

149.speaker: Volo
149.text: And you would use that power for good? A risky proposition.

91.speaker: Volo
91.text: It is possible you could turn it against the city's enemies, but it would be better to purge yourself of Bhaal's influence entirely.
91.context: NodeContext: contemplating the possibility of the first proposition, but unconvinced

161.speaker: Volo
161.text: Still - perhaps Irenicus' study will help you to work out some techniques for your own beastly form.
161.context: NodeContext: trying to be reassuring in a bleak situation (irɛnIkIs)

116.speaker: Volo
116.context: NodeContext: dramatic - invoking the name of a legendary monster

70.speaker: Volo
70.text: It is said the children of Bhaal are claimed throughout their sleep, ever-disturbed by visions of a life of bloodshed and terror.

109.speaker: Volo
109.text: Once they have seen too much, once these dreams drive their minds to break, they are beset by the Slayer.

42.speaker: Volo
42.text: It is a beast of unspeakable violence that consumes all in its path, including the soul of the one who is host to it.

46.speaker: Volo
46.text: A genius. Exiled from his home in the elven paradise of Suldanessellar when he attempted to seize the power of life itself, he instead turned his magnificent mind to murder on a grand scale.
46.context: NodeContext: telling the story of a historic villain (sull-duh-ness-seh-llar)

103.speaker: Volo
103.text: That is how he came to crave the power of the Bhaalspawn. He saw them not as living things, but as tools for his own machinations.
103.context: NodeContext: telling the story of a historic villain

49.speaker: Volo
49.text: In the end, though Irenicus took the form of the Slayer for himself, it was a Bhaalspawn who thwarted him. The same that saved Baldur's Gate.
49.context: NodeContext: telling the story of a historic villain ((irɛnIkIs))

12.speaker: Player
12.text: I'll need more than a book to face Bhaal's Chosen.

78.speaker: Volo
78.text: Quite so. I was rather hoping you'd gathered all the rest of the adventuring paraphernalia yourself. You'll need every advantage.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: About my companion - do you think I can trust a Bhaalspawn to do the right thing when the time comes?

13.speaker: Volo
13.text: Without you, it is entirely possible your companion would already be lost. Bhaal's will is not easily overcome.
13.context: NodeContext: reassuring and sympathetic - speaking of a dire situation

151.speaker: Volo
151.text: But the saga of the Bhaalspawn is not the story of a hero fighting alone against their own bloody inheritance.

24.speaker: Volo
24.text: It is a story of friendships forged and alliances that did not break even in the darkest times.

27.speaker: Volo
27.text: This is your saga, my friend. And I hope I shall have the honour of documenting its happy conclusion.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: This is a daunting task - I should begin my preparations now.

152.speaker: Volo
152.text: I am a living witness to Bhaal's defeat those hundred years ago, so I know your battle against him is not futile. He can be stopped.

77.speaker: Volo
77.text: But not all of those who stood against him survived - and those who did were never the same again.

57.speaker: Volo
57.text: I wish you luck, my friend. And I hope that when I see you again, you'll be in one piece. Two or three at most.
57.context: NodeContext: a hint of tragedy, even with the silliness of the ending. Volo isn't self-aware enough to realise he's being ridiculous

32.speaker: Player
32.text: I've already slain Myrkul's Chosen - I can handle this.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: I've already slain two Chosen - I can handle one more.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: I hope so too - I think I can be the hero the city needs.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: My vintage is much darker - I will claim my birthright, and the power that comes with it.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: I'm afraid I'll never be a hero. My urges compel me to do terrible things.

137.speaker: Volo
137.text: If you did not have the strength to resist those urges, you would have become a savage beast long ago.

97.speaker: Volo
97.text: I have been known to exaggerate the truth on occasion, but do not take me for a fool.

52.speaker: Volo
52.text: I believe the city may need a Bhaalspawn - may need you - if it is to survive this new crisis.

6.speaker: Volo
6.text: Orin is his Chosen, and like Sarevok before her, she is able to take on the savage form of the Slayer.
6.context: NodeContext: his usual flamboyant self, but with a hint of dread - this is dire news (O-rin) (SAH-reh-vok)

141.speaker: Volo
141.text: If the Slayer is not stopped, it will slaughter every living thing in this city. As one of those things, I'm particularly eager to stop it.
141.context: NodeContext: his usual flamboyant self, but with a hint of dread - this is dire news (O-rin) (SAH-reh-vok)

89.speaker: Volo
89.text: And there is a way. I have a study of the beast, penned by the wizard Irenicus himself. It contains all of the knowledge needed to slay the Slayer.

100.speaker: Volo
100.text: Now I just need a brave adventurer willing to face Bhaal's Chosen, and to put the knowledge into practice.
100.context: NodeContext: saying this in front of a 'brave adventurer' and hoping they'll take the bait

76.speaker: Volo
76.text: Marvellous! The people do like a returning favourite.
76.context: NodeContext: delighted - the 'returning favourite' is Minsc, who he's talking to right now

4.speaker: Volo
4.text: Wonderful! I can scarcely think of anyone more suitable.
4.context: NodeContext: He's not being sarcastic when he undermines the person he's talking to with his 'scarcely think of anyone', he's just being bluntly honest

129.speaker: Player
129.text: Don't look at me. I'm not about to volunteer.

28.speaker: Volo
28.text: Oh, but you must! There's nobody else available.
28.context: NodeContext: he's not being sarcastic - he's just that blunt

107.speaker: Volo
107.text: It will serve you well. 'A Study of the Slayer', penned by Jon Irenicus. It's a one-of-a-kind, so do try to keep it away from the inevitable bloodbath.
107.context: NodeContext: after handing over a book which he prizes highly (irɛnIkIs)

92.speaker: Player
92.text: Why don't you go fight the Slayer yourself?

38.speaker: Volo
38.text: I have a very particular set of extraordinary skills. But fighting the bestial avatars of murderous gods is not among them.
38.context: NodeContext: somebody just suggested he fight a monster, and he's

90.speaker: Player
90.text: Somebody will rise to the task.

54.speaker: Volo
54.text: I don't think so. Not this time. It has to be you.

83.speaker: Volo
83.text: I really thought you were the one.

9.speaker: Volo
9.text: Perhaps it's time I started my field research for a Guide to Anywhere But Here. Ta-ta.
9.context: NodeContext: perparing to scarper, realising the city is doomed

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Orin may not be the only Chosen of Bhaal - I believe we travel with another.

50.speaker: Volo
50.text: Then perhaps we have hope yet.

134.speaker: Volo
134.text: A child of Bhaal saved this city once before, by slaughtering his foul siblings. Your companion may be able to repeat history - to be the hero we need.

154.speaker: Volo
154.text: Take Irenicus' 'A Study of the Slayer'. And when you face Orin, be sure your friend is by your side.

2.speaker: Volo
2.text: But I suppose you'll have to deal with the illithids first. Please, do tell me when you've thwarted every apocalypse that's currently in motion.
2.context: NodeContext: he's serious about this - emphasis on 'every' not because he's being sarcastic, but because he's frustrated that the player is busy dealing wtih so many apocalypses (ih-LITH-id)

80.speaker: Player
80.text: I assume you criticised Archduke Gortash. He controls the city now.

65.speaker: Volo
65.text: Pish-posh. That strutting tyrant has a long reach and a steel fist, but he's a puppy dog compared to the real horror that haunts our streets.
65.context: NodeContext: dismissive, and enjoying the build-up to the reveal he's setting up

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Did you speak out against the cult of the Absolute? They have eyes everywhere.

81.speaker: Volo
81.text: It is not the eyes that I fear, it is the intelligence behind them. The Absolute is merely the outward form of something far more insidious.
81.context: NodeContext: enjoying the build-up to the reveal he's setting up

143.speaker: Player
143.text: I just assumed decades of spreading lies and misinformation had caught up with you.

111.speaker: Volo
111.text: Nonsense! It is my dedication to truth that endangers my wellbeing, and I have uncovered the most startling truth imaginable.
111.context: NodeContext: he's just been insulted, but he's so egotistical it barely registers

147.speaker: Volo
147.text: Whatever happens next, be sure that I will document it all as accurately as possible.
